models.name: Neck, Shoulders & Upper Back
models.description: Detailed anatomy of the neck, shoulder, and upper back region showing muscles, bones, and connective tissues

viewpoints.name: Front View
viewpoints.description: Frontal view of the neck and shoulder region showing anterior muscles and bone structure
viewpoints.clinicalContext: Essential for understanding neck tension, forward head posture, and anterior shoulder pain. Helps identify muscle imbalances that contribute to neck knots and jaw aches.
commonUseCases: Diagnosing tech neck and forward head posture
Planning massage therapy for neck tension

viewpoints.name: Right Shoulder
viewpoints.description: Lateral view of the right shoulder showing rotator cuff and shoulder stabilizers
viewpoints.clinicalContext: Critical for diagnosing rotator cuff injuries, shoulder impingement, and frozen shoulder. Shows the complex interplay of muscles that stabilize and move the shoulder joint.
commonUseCases: Planning physical therapy for shoulder rehabilitation

viewpoints.name: Back of Shoulder and Neck
viewpoints.description: Posterior view highlighting upper back muscles and neck extensors
viewpoints.clinicalContext: Most relevant for addressing upper back tension, neck knots, and scapular winging. This view is essential for massage therapists and chiropractors treating upper body pain and poor posture.
commonUseCases: Treating chronic neck knots and tension headaches
Addressing upper back pain from desk work
Identifying trigger points causing referred pain to jaw and head

viewpoints.name: Left Shoulder
viewpoints.description: Lateral view of the left shoulder showing rotator cuff and shoulder stabilizers
viewpoints.clinicalContext: Mirror view of the right shoulder, essential for comparing bilateral shoulder anatomy and identifying asymmetries that may contribute to pain or dysfunction.
commonUseCases: Comparing left vs right shoulder anatomy

models.name: Male Skeletal System
models.description: Complete skeletal system showing all major bones of the human body

viewpoints.name: Front View
viewpoints.description: Full frontal view of the skeletal system showing the anterior perspective of all major bones
viewpoints.clinicalContext: This view is essential for identifying anterior bone structures, assessing symmetry, and evaluating conditions like scoliosis or pelvic tilt. Medical students use this to learn bone names and positions.

viewpoints.name: Side View
viewpoints.description: Lateral view emphasizing the vertebral column and spinal curvatures
viewpoints.clinicalContext: Critical for assessing spinal curvatures (lordosis, kyphosis), evaluating vertebral alignment, and understanding the natural S-curve of the spine. Essential for chiropractors and orthopedic specialists.

viewpoints.name: Head Close-up
viewpoints.description: Detailed view of the skull and facial bones
viewpoints.clinicalContext: Important for dental professionals, maxillofacial surgeons, and neurologists. Used to understand cranial bone structure, identify fracture points, and plan reconstructive surgeries.
commonUseCases: Understanding brain protection and cranial anatomy

viewpoints.name: Lower Body View
viewpoints.description: Focused view of the lower extremities and pelvic region
viewpoints.clinicalContext: Essential for orthopedic surgeons and physical therapists working with hip replacements, knee injuries, or gait analysis. Critical for understanding weight-bearing mechanics and lower limb biomechanics.

models.name: Male Muscular System
models.description: Complete muscular system showing major muscle groups

viewpoints.name: Anterior Muscles
viewpoints.description: Frontal view showing major anterior muscle groups
viewpoints.clinicalContext: Key for personal trainers and physical therapists understanding muscle imbalances, planning strength training, and rehabilitation after injury. Shows muscles involved in pushing movements.

viewpoints.name: Posterior Muscles
viewpoints.description: Posterior view emphasizing back and posterior chain muscles
viewpoints.clinicalContext: Critical for understanding pulling movements, back pain sources, and posterior chain development. Essential for treating lower back pain and improving athletic performance.

metadata.author: Anatomy Viewer Project
metadata.description: Database of anatomical models with predefined viewpoints and educational context
